code:
export const advicePosts = [{
  title: "Stay Organized from Day One",
  author: "Anonymous",
  timeAgo: "1 hr. ago",
  tag: "Study tips",
  content: "One of the best things I did was using a planner or a scheduling app to keep track of assignments and deadlines. Don't wait until the middle of the semester to get organized — start early, and stay consistent!",
  likes: 143,
  hearts: 60
}, {
  title: "Use Practice Tests for Exam Prep",
  author: "Anonymous",
  timeAgo: "1 hr. ago",
  tag: "Test Preparation",
  content: "One of the best ways to prepare for exams, especially for subjects like math and science, is to take as many practice tests as possible. These will help you get familiar with the format, identify weak areas, and improve time management. Don't just study passively—simulate the exam environment and time yourself!",
  likes: 0,
  hearts: 0
}, {
  title: "Create a Personalized Study Schedule for Exams",
  author: "Anonymous",
  timeAgo: "2 hrs. ago",
  tag: "Study tips",
  content: "Preparing for exams can be overwhelming, especially when you have multiple tests around the same time. What helped me the most was creating a detailed, personalized study schedule at least two weeks before exams. Break down your subjects and prioritize the harder topics first. Allocate study blocks for each subject and be realistic about how much time you need.",
  likes: 112,
  hearts: 33
}, {
  title: "Maximize Your Time as a Commuter Student",
  author: "Anonymous",
  timeAgo: "3 hrs. ago",
  tag: "Commuter Student Tips",
  content: "Being a commuter student can be tough, but with some planning, you can make the most of your time on campus. Try to block your classes together on the same days so you're not traveling back and forth too often. Between classes, make use of campus resources like the library, study rooms, or quiet areas to get work done.",
  likes: 89,
  hearts: 41
}, {
  title: "Network Early for Internship Opportunities",
  author: "Anonymous",
  timeAgo: "4 hrs. ago",
  tag: "Internships",
  content: "Don't wait until your junior or senior year to start networking for internships. Attend career fairs, join professional clubs related to your field, and reach out to alumni as early as your freshman year. Building relationships early can lead to amazing internship opportunities later on.",
  likes: 201,
  hearts: 78
}, {
  title: "Make the Most of Office Hours",
  author: "Anonymous",
  timeAgo: "5 hrs. ago",
  tag: "Professors",
  content: "Office hours are an underutilized resource. Don't be shy about visiting your professors during their office hours, even if you're not struggling in class. It's a great opportunity to clarify concepts, get advice on projects, and build a relationship that could lead to research opportunities or strong recommendation letters.",
  likes: 167,
  hearts: 55
}, {
  title: "Budget-Friendly Meal Prep for College Students",
  author: "Anonymous",
  timeAgo: "6 hrs. ago",
  tag: "Financial Aid & Scholarships",
  content: "Eating out can quickly drain your budget. Learn to meal prep! Buy ingredients in bulk, cook large batches on weekends, and portion them out for the week. It's healthier, cheaper, and saves time during busy weekdays. Look for student discounts at local grocery stores too!",
  likes: 230,
  hearts: 102
}, {
  title: "Leverage Campus Tech Resources",
  author: "Anonymous",
  timeAgo: "7 hrs. ago",
  tag: "Tech & Tools",
  content: "Many students don't realize how many tech resources are available on campus. From free software licenses to high-performance computing labs, make sure you're taking advantage of all the tech your tuition covers. Check with your IT department for a full list of available resources.",
  likes: 78,
  hearts: 25
}, {
  title: "Balance Academics and Social Life",
  author: "Anonymous",
  timeAgo: "8 hrs. ago",
  tag: "Social Life",
  content: "While academics should be your priority, don't forget to enjoy your college experience. Join clubs, attend campus events, and make time for friends. A balanced life will actually improve your academic performance by reducing stress and preventing burnout.",
  likes: 189,
  hearts: 87
}, {
  title: "Maximize Financial Aid Opportunities",
  author: "Anonymous",
  timeAgo: "9 hrs. ago",
  tag: "Financial Aid & Scholarships",
  content: "Don't just rely on the big, well-known scholarships. Look for smaller, local scholarships or those specific to your major. These often have less competition. Also, reapply for financial aid every year – your situation might change, leading to more aid.",
  likes: 256,
  hearts: 120
}];

sourcesContent:
export const advicePosts = [
  {
    title: "Stay Organized from Day One",
    author: "Anonymous",
    timeAgo: "1 hr. ago",
    tag: "Study tips",
    content:
      "One of the best things I did was using a planner or a scheduling app to keep track of assignments and deadlines. Don't wait until the middle of the semester to get organized — start early, and stay consistent!",
    likes: 143,
    hearts: 60,
  },
  {
    title: "Use Practice Tests for Exam Prep",
    author: "Anonymous",
    timeAgo: "1 hr. ago",
    tag: "Test Preparation",
    content:
      "One of the best ways to prepare for exams, especially for subjects like math and science, is to take as many practice tests as possible. These will help you get familiar with the format, identify weak areas, and improve time management. Don't just study passively—simulate the exam environment and time yourself!",
    likes: 0,
    hearts: 0,
  },
  {
    title: "Create a Personalized Study Schedule for Exams",
    author: "Anonymous",
    timeAgo: "2 hrs. ago",
    tag: "Study tips",
    content:
      "Preparing for exams can be overwhelming, especially when you have multiple tests around the same time. What helped me the most was creating a detailed, personalized study schedule at least two weeks before exams. Break down your subjects and prioritize the harder topics first. Allocate study blocks for each subject and be realistic about how much time you need.",
    likes: 112,
    hearts: 33,
  },
  {
    title: "Maximize Your Time as a Commuter Student",
    author: "Anonymous",
    timeAgo: "3 hrs. ago",
    tag: "Commuter Student Tips",
    content:
      "Being a commuter student can be tough, but with some planning, you can make the most of your time on campus. Try to block your classes together on the same days so you're not traveling back and forth too often. Between classes, make use of campus resources like the library, study rooms, or quiet areas to get work done.",
    likes: 89,
    hearts: 41,
  },
  {
    title: "Network Early for Internship Opportunities",
    author: "Anonymous",
    timeAgo: "4 hrs. ago",
    tag: "Internships",
    content:
      "Don't wait until your junior or senior year to start networking for internships. Attend career fairs, join professional clubs related to your field, and reach out to alumni as early as your freshman year. Building relationships early can lead to amazing internship opportunities later on.",
    likes: 201,
    hearts: 78,
  },
  {
    title: "Make the Most of Office Hours",
    author: "Anonymous",
    timeAgo: "5 hrs. ago",
    tag: "Professors",
    content:
      "Office hours are an underutilized resource. Don't be shy about visiting your professors during their office hours, even if you're not struggling in class. It's a great opportunity to clarify concepts, get advice on projects, and build a relationship that could lead to research opportunities or strong recommendation letters.",
    likes: 167,
    hearts: 55,
  },
  {
    title: "Budget-Friendly Meal Prep for College Students",
    author: "Anonymous",
    timeAgo: "6 hrs. ago",
    tag: "Financial Aid & Scholarships",
    content:
      "Eating out can quickly drain your budget. Learn to meal prep! Buy ingredients in bulk, cook large batches on weekends, and portion them out for the week. It's healthier, cheaper, and saves time during busy weekdays. Look for student discounts at local grocery stores too!",
    likes: 230,
    hearts: 102,
  },
  {
    title: "Leverage Campus Tech Resources",
    author: "Anonymous",
    timeAgo: "7 hrs. ago",
    tag: "Tech & Tools",
    content:
      "Many students don't realize how many tech resources are available on campus. From free software licenses to high-performance computing labs, make sure you're taking advantage of all the tech your tuition covers. Check with your IT department for a full list of available resources.",
    likes: 78,
    hearts: 25,
  },
  {
    title: "Balance Academics and Social Life",
    author: "Anonymous",
    timeAgo: "8 hrs. ago",
    tag: "Social Life",
    content:
      "While academics should be your priority, don't forget to enjoy your college experience. Join clubs, attend campus events, and make time for friends. A balanced life will actually improve your academic performance by reducing stress and preventing burnout.",
    likes: 189,
    hearts: 87,
  },
  {
    title: "Maximize Financial Aid Opportunities",
    author: "Anonymous",
    timeAgo: "9 hrs. ago",
    tag: "Financial Aid & Scholarships",
    content:
      "Don't just rely on the big, well-known scholarships. Look for smaller, local scholarships or those specific to your major. These often have less competition. Also, reapply for financial aid every year – your situation might change, leading to more aid.",
    likes: 256,
    hearts: 120,
  },
];
